query: quantum computing error correction fault tolerance NISQ variational quantum algorithms quantum advantage surface code qubit coherence quantum gates

concepts.label: Tianyan Quantum Cloud Platform
concepts.description: A cloud service providing remote access to a superconducting quantum processor with demonstrated quantum advantage capabilities.

concepts.label: Zuchongzhi 3.0
concepts.description: A superconducting quantum processor architecture that serves as the design basis for the Tianyan quantum hardware.

concepts.label: Tianyan-287
concepts.description: A superconducting quantum processor prototype with 105 qubits accessible via cloud platform achieving high operational fidelities.

concepts.label: superconducting qubit
concepts.description: A quantum bit implemented using superconducting circuits, forming the basic computational unit of the Tianyan processor.

concepts.label: quantum advantage
concepts.description: The capability of a quantum computer to solve specific computational tasks faster than the best known classical algorithms on state-of-the-art supercomputers.

concepts.label: random circuit sampling
concepts.description: A benchmark task that applies random quantum gates to a quantum circuit and samples the output distribution, used to demonstrate quantum advantage.

concepts.label: two-qubit gate
concepts.description: A quantum operation acting on two qubits with 99.56% fidelity in the Tianyan platform.

concepts.label: readout fidelity
concepts.description: The accuracy of measuring and extracting quantum information from qubits, achieved at 98.7% in Tianyan-287.

concepts.label: gate fidelity
concepts.description: The accuracy of quantum gate operations; Tianyan achieves 99.90% for single-qubit and 99.56% for two-qubit gates.

concepts.label: Cqlib SDK
concepts.description: An open-source software development kit designed for programming quantum systems using extended quantum circuits, operators, and primitives.

concepts.label: quantum circuit
concepts.description: A sequence of quantum gates applied to qubits; the fundamental programming model for quantum computation.

concepts.label: quantum operator
concepts.description: Mathematical objects representing quantum observables or transformations used in quantum circuit construction and simulation.

concepts.label: quantum primitive
concepts.description: Basic building blocks or fundamental operations in quantum programming provided by Cqlib for circuit construction.

concepts.label: Continuous-time quantum error correction
concepts.description: An approach to protecting quantum information from noise in which both noise and error correcting operations are treated as continuous-time processes.

concepts.label: Subsystem principle
concepts.description: The principle that protected quantum information is contained in a subsystem of the Hilbert space rather than the full system.

concepts.label: Continuous weak measurements
concepts.description: Measurement operations applied continuously in time that weakly couple to the quantum system without strongly projecting its state.

concepts.label: Feedback control
concepts.description: Real-time correction operations applied based on measurement outcomes to suppress errors and protect quantum information.

concepts.label: Encoded basis
concepts.description: A choice of basis for analyzing the system state in which the subsystem containing protected information is explicitly represented.

concepts.label: Single qubit protection
concepts.description: Protocols and strategies for protecting the coherence and information of a single qubit from decoherence and noise.

concepts.label: Weak unitary operations
concepts.description: Unitary operations applied weakly and continuously to the system to correct errors and maintain quantum coherence.

concepts.label: Direct feedback
concepts.description: Error correction scheme in which feedback operations are applied directly based on measurement outcomes.

concepts.label: Indirect feedback
concepts.description: Error correction scheme in which feedback is applied indirectly through measurement-conditioned operations.

concepts.label: Markovian decoherence
concepts.description: Decoherence dynamics with no memory effects, where the future evolution depends only on the current state.

concepts.label: Quantum Zeno regime
concepts.description: A dynamical regime where frequent measurements or operations prevent transitions away from the initial state, inhibiting decoherence.

concepts.label: Time resolution
concepts.description: The temporal granularity or frequency of weak error-correcting operations applied to the quantum system.

concepts.label: Hilbert space subsystem
concepts.description: A factorized subspace of the total Hilbert space that decouples from the environment and retains protected quantum information.

concepts.label: spin-cat code
concepts.description: Quantum error-correcting code that encodes a qubit in a large spin qudit using superpositions of angular momentum coherent states, analogous to continuous variable cat encoding.

concepts.label: quantum error correction
concepts.description: Technique for protecting quantum information against decoherence and noise by encoding logical qubits redundantly and detecting/correcting errors.

concepts.label: fault-tolerant quantum computation
concepts.description: Framework for performing quantum computation reliably despite errors, using error-correcting codes and gates designed to prevent error propagation.

concepts.label: angular momentum operators
concepts.description: Quantum operators representing components of angular momentum (spin) that characterize the dominant error sources in spin-based qudits.

concepts.label: phase errors
concepts.description: Quantum errors that affect the phase relationships between superposition states, analogous to phase-flip errors in qubit systems.

concepts.label: amplitude errors
concepts.description: Quantum errors that alter the populations and amplitudes of quantum states, corrected using measurement-free error correction schemes.

concepts.label: CNOT gate
concepts.description: Two-qubit controlled-NOT gate that implements conditional bit-flip operations; here rank-preserving to maintain spherical tensor structure.

concepts.label: spherical tensor operators
concepts.description: Mathematical objects characterizing angular momentum eigenstates; their rank structure is preserved by suitable gate operations.

concepts.label: error threshold
concepts.description: Critical physical error rate below which logical error rate decreases with increasing code distance; spin-cat code achieves higher threshold than standard qubit codes.

concepts.label: universal gate set
concepts.description: Collection of quantum gates sufficient to implement arbitrary unitary operations; identified here to preserve dominant error structure.

concepts.label: measurement-free error correction
concepts.description: Error correction scheme that corrects errors without performing explicit syndrome measurements, used here for amplitude errors.

concepts.label: neutral-atom quantum computing
concepts.description: Quantum computing platform using neutral atoms trapped in optical lattices or tweezers, with nuclear spins encoding qudits.

concepts.label: Rydberg blockade
concepts.description: Interaction mechanism in neutral-atom systems where excited Rydberg states prevent neighboring atoms from being excited, enabling entangling gates.

concepts.label: quantum control
concepts.description: Techniques for manipulating quantum systems using external fields and pulses to implement desired unitary operations.

concepts.label: qudit encoding
concepts.description: Encoding of quantum information in a d-dimensional quantum system (d > 2), here using large spin states in nuclear spins.

concepts.label: NISQ technology
concepts.description: Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum devices with 50-100 qubits, capable of performing tasks beyond classical computers but limited by gate noise.

concepts.label: quantum gates
concepts.description: Basic quantum operations that manipulate qubits; subject to noise in NISQ devices, limiting circuit depth and reliability.

concepts.label: quantum circuits
concepts.description: Sequences of quantum gates applied to qubits; their executable size is limited by accumulated noise in NISQ era.

concepts.label: gate noise
concepts.description: Errors and decoherence affecting quantum gates, constraining the reliable execution depth of quantum circuits.

concepts.label: qubits
concepts.description: Quantum bits, the fundamental units of quantum information; NISQ devices contain 50-100 qubits.

concepts.label: many-body quantum physics
concepts.description: Study of quantum systems with multiple interacting particles; a key application domain for NISQ devices.

concepts.label: classical computers
concepts.description: Traditional digital computers whose computational capabilities are surpassed by near-term NISQ devices in specific tasks.

concepts.label: Entanglement-assisted quantum error-correcting codes
concepts.description: A class of quantum error-correcting codes that leverage pre-shared entanglement between sender and receiver to improve code parameters and performance.

concepts.label: Entanglement
concepts.description: Quantum correlation between two or more subsystems such that the joint state cannot be factorized into independent subsystems.

concepts.label: Code parameters
concepts.description: Metrics characterizing quantum codes, including number of physical qubits, logical qubits, and minimum distance.

concepts.label: Sender-receiver channel
concepts.description: The quantum communication link over which quantum information is transmitted and subject to environmental noise and errors.

concepts.label: Holonomic quantum computation
concepts.description: A quantum computation approach using geometric phases and adiabatic evolution to manipulate quantum information.

concepts.label: Stabilizer codes
concepts.description: A class of quantum error-correcting codes defined by a stabilizer group whose eigenspace encodes logical qubits.

concepts.label: Adiabatic dragging
concepts.description: A technique for transporting quantum states along a parameter-dependent path while maintaining instantaneous eigenstate configuration.

concepts.label: Logical information
concepts.description: Quantum information encoded in the protected subspace of an error-correcting code.

concepts.label: Subsystem
concepts.description: A partition of a larger quantum system containing a subset of the physical degrees of freedom.

concepts.label: Geometric phase
concepts.description: A phase acquired by a quantum state under adiabatic evolution through a closed loop in parameter space, independent of energy eigenvalues.

concepts.label: coherent states
concepts.description: Quantum states that minimize uncertainty relations and behave most classically, with well-defined phase and amplitude.

concepts.label: Schrödinger approach
concepts.description: Seminal foundational perspective on coherent states based on wave packet dynamics and minimum uncertainty.

concepts.label: quantum optics
concepts.description: Experimental and theoretical study of quantum properties of light, photons, and light-matter interactions.

concepts.label: quantum gravity
concepts.description: Theoretical framework attempting to reconcile quantum mechanics with general relativity and gravity at all scales.

concepts.label: uncertainty relations
concepts.description: Mathematical bounds constraining the simultaneous precision of complementary observable pairs.

concepts.label: wave packet
concepts.description: Localized quantum state formed by superposition of waves, describing particle-like behaviour.

concepts.label: phase space
concepts.description: Mathematical space parameterized by canonical coordinates and momenta describing classical and quantum dynamics.

concepts.label: quantization
concepts.description: Mathematical procedure converting classical observables and Poisson brackets into quantum operators and commutation relations.

concepts.label: classical limit
concepts.description: Limit regime where quantum systems approximate classical behaviour, typically as ℏ→0.

concepts.label: light-matter interaction
concepts.description: Coupling between electromagnetic radiation and atomic or molecular systems in quantum optics.

concepts.label: quantum low-density parity-check codes
concepts.description: Quantum error-correcting codes with sparse parity-check matrices enabling constant-rate encoding with linear minimum distance.

concepts.label: qubit overhead
concepts.description: The ratio of physical qubits required to logical qubits needed for error-corrected quantum computation.

concepts.label: circuit-level noise model
concepts.description: Noise model characterizing errors on quantum gates and qubits at the circuit level rather than in the asymptotic limit.

concepts.label: diamond norm
concepts.description: Mathematical norm measuring the maximum distinguishability between quantum channels, capturing both stochastic and non-stochastic noise.

concepts.label: stochastic noise
concepts.description: Noise characterized by random, incoherent errors with well-defined probability distributions.

concepts.label: non-stochastic noise
concepts.description: Noise including coherent and correlated errors that cannot be described as simple probabilistic channels.

concepts.label: amplitude damping
concepts.description: Noise process describing energy dissipation and decay of quantum states to lower energy eigenstates.

concepts.label: fault-tolerant error correction
concepts.description: Error correction scheme designed to correct errors without introducing new errors from the correction process itself.

concepts.label: logic gate implementation
concepts.description: Methods for realizing logical quantum gates on encoded qubits that maintain error-correction properties.

concepts.label: code rate
concepts.description: The ratio of logical qubits to physical qubits in a quantum error-correcting code.

concepts.label: minimum distance
concepts.description: The minimum weight of errors detectable and correctable by a quantum error-correcting code; larger distance improves reliability.

concepts.label: polylogarithmic overhead
concepts.description: Resource overhead scaling as polylogarithm of problem size; typical in traditional fault-tolerant approaches.

concepts.label: universal gate
concepts.description: A quantum gate or set of gates from which any unitary operation on qubits can be constructed.

concepts.label: quantum computation
concepts.description: Computation performed using quantum mechanical phenomena and qubits as the fundamental information units.

concepts.label: three-bit gate
concepts.description: A quantum logic gate operating on three qubits; the Deutsch gate is a canonical example.

concepts.label: universality
concepts.description: The property that a set of gates or operations is sufficient to generate any desired unitary transformation.

concepts.label: Rydberg atoms
concepts.description: Highly excited atomic states with one or more electrons in high principal quantum number orbitals, exhibiting strong dipole-dipole interactions.

concepts.label: Optical trapping
concepts.description: Technique using focused laser beams to confine and position neutral atoms in three-dimensional potential wells.

concepts.label: Quantum simulation
concepts.description: Use of a controllable quantum system to model and predict the behavior of another quantum system, especially many-body systems.

concepts.label: State preparation
concepts.description: Initialization of qubits into a specified quantum state with high fidelity before computation or simulation.

concepts.label: Quantum readout
concepts.description: Measurement process to extract classical information from quantum states with minimal decoherence and high accuracy.

concepts.label: Multiqubit gates
concepts.description: Quantum logic operations that entangle or correlate the states of two or more qubits simultaneously.

concepts.label: Quantum many-body Hamiltonian
concepts.description: Total energy operator describing interactions and dynamics of systems with many interacting quantum particles.

concepts.label: Linear array of emitters
concepts.description: A one-dimensional arrangement of quantum light sources that generate entangled photonic resource states through sequential interactions.

concepts.label: Delay line
concepts.description: An optical component that introduces temporal delays to photons, used in photonic quantum processors to facilitate interactions between emitted photons.

concepts.label: Resource state
concepts.description: An entangled quantum state generated off-line and used as a consumable resource in measurement-based or gate-based quantum computation.

concepts.label: Logical error rate
concepts.description: The rate at which errors occur on encoded logical qubits, reflecting the effective failure rate of fault-tolerant quantum information.

concepts.label: Delay line error
concepts.description: Errors arising from imperfections in delay lines, including photon loss, dispersion, and temporal decoherence of stored photonic states.

concepts.label: Break-even point
concepts.description: The threshold condition where the overhead cost of error correction begins to yield a net reduction in logical error rate.

concepts.label: Error suppression
concepts.description: The phenomenon where increasing code distance or physical resources leads to exponential reduction in the logical error rate below threshold.

concepts.label: Photon stream
concepts.description: A continuous sequence of photons that interact with emitters to generate entangled states in photonic quantum processors.

concepts.label: quantum link models
concepts.description: Lattice regularizations of gauge theories using quantum spins on links to represent gauge fields in discrete spacetime.

concepts.label: lattice gauge theories
concepts.description: Discretized formulation of gauge theories on a spatial lattice, amenable to numerical simulation and quantum synthesis.

concepts.label: quantum field theory limit
concepts.description: Continuum limit in which a lattice regularization reproduces the dynamics and symmetries of the underlying continuum quantum field theory.

concepts.label: far-from-equilibrium dynamics
concepts.description: Non-equilibrium evolution of quantum systems following a sudden change in Hamiltonian (quench), far from thermal or ground states.

concepts.label: quantum quench
concepts.description: Sudden change in system parameters, used to prepare far-from-equilibrium initial states and study relaxation and coherent evolution.

concepts.label: Loschmidt return rate
concepts.description: Logarithm of the squared overlap between evolved state and initial state, probing coherence and dephasing in quench dynamics.

concepts.label: chiral condensate
concepts.description: Order parameter characterizing spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry, measured as a bilinear fermion expectation value.

concepts.label: link spin length
concepts.description: Quantum spin representation on lattice links; half-integer or integer values determine the dimension of the local Hilbert space.

concepts.label: infinite matrix product states
concepts.description: Variational tensor-network ansatz for representing infinite 1D quantum states, used to simulate thermodynamic limits numerically.

concepts.label: electric-field coupling
concepts.description: Interaction strength between the quantum link model and the electric field degrees of freedom on the lattice.

concepts.label: Kitaev quantum double model
concepts.description: A 2D lattice model with gauge symmetry for finite groups that exhibits topological quantum order and ground-state degeneracy.

concepts.label: topological quantum order
concepts.description: A phase of matter with long-range entanglement characterised by non-local ground-state degeneracy and topological robustness against local perturbations.

concepts.label: ground space
concepts.description: The subspace of a Hamiltonian spanned by all zero-energy eigenstates.

concepts.label: energy density
concepts.description: The expectation value of the Hamiltonian per unit cell or local energy per region.

concepts.label: gauge-invariant state
concepts.description: A quantum state that is invariant under local gauge transformations generated by Gauss's law constraints.

concepts.label: contractible region
concepts.description: A topologically simply-connected spatial region in which loops can be continuously deformed to a point.

concepts.label: reduced density matrix
concepts.description: The density matrix of a subsystem obtained by tracing out all other degrees of freedom.

concepts.label: non-Abelian flux
concepts.description: A non-commuting gauge flux or topological charge arising from non-Abelian gauge symmetry.

concepts.label: Wilson loop
concepts.description: An order parameter in lattice gauge theory measuring the phase or group element of parallel transport around a closed loop.

concepts.label: lattice gauge theory
concepts.description: A discrete formulation of gauge theory on a spatial lattice with gauge fields on bonds and matter on sites.

concepts.label: topological entanglement entropy
concepts.description: A universal constant term in the entanglement entropy that characterises the topological order independent of region geometry.

concepts.label: commuting observables
concepts.description: A set of quantum observables that mutually commute and can be simultaneously measured without uncertainty.

concepts.label: thermalisation
concepts.description: Process by which a quantum system reaches thermal equilibrium with a heat bath, characterized by exponential decay to Boltzmann distribution.

concepts.label: Unruh temperature
concepts.description: Temperature perceived by an accelerating observer in flat spacetime, proportional to their proper acceleration divided by the Boltzmann constant.

concepts.label: quantum superposition
concepts.description: Coherent linear combination of quantum states; a fundamental feature of quantum mechanics enabling interference effects.

concepts.label: relativistic noninertial reference frames
concepts.description: Accelerated reference frames in special or general relativity where Lorentz invariance is maintained but inertial forces appear.

concepts.label: quantum thermodynamics
concepts.description: Study of thermodynamic laws and heat processes in the quantum regime where coherence, entanglement, and work fluctuations are significant.

concepts.label: relativistic quantum information
concepts.description: Framework combining quantum information theory with special and general relativity to study information in relativistic systems.

concepts.label: quantum-controlled thermalisations
concepts.description: Application of thermalisation channels conditioned on quantum control parameters, allowing superpositions of thermalisation processes.

concepts.label: Rindler wedge
concepts.description: Region of spacetime accessible to a uniformly accelerating observer; the natural coordinate system for studying Unruh radiation.

concepts.label: field modes
concepts.description: Fundamental degrees of freedom of a quantum field, indexed by momentum and polarization; the basis for mode decomposition in QFT.

concepts.label: proper acceleration
concepts.description: Acceleration measured in the instantaneous rest frame of an observer; an invariant quantity independent of reference frame.

concepts.label: spatial translation superposition
concepts.description: Quantum superposition of accelerated trajectories differing by spatial displacement while maintaining the same proper acceleration profile.

concepts.label: orthogonal field modes
concepts.description: Set of quantum field modes with zero inner product, representing incommensurate excitations with no overlap.

concepts.label: thermalisation channel
concepts.description: Quantum operation or coupling mechanism that drives a system toward thermal equilibrium with a reservoir.

concepts.label: categorical quantum mechanics
concepts.description: Framework for studying quantum phenomena using category theory and diagrammatic calculus, emphasizing compositional structure.

concepts.label: nonlocal games
concepts.description: Multiplayer games where players can share quantum entanglement but cannot communicate, used to test quantum correlations.

concepts.label: quantum questions and answers
concepts.description: Extension of classical game questions to quantum-valued objects, allowing superposition and entanglement in game inputs and outputs.

concepts.label: quantum sets
concepts.description: Mathematical structures defined as special symmetric dagger Frobenius algebras used to encode quantum objects in categorical quantum mechanics.

concepts.label: quantum functions
concepts.description: Maps between quantum sets preserving their algebraic structure, generalizing classical functions to the quantum domain.

concepts.label: diagrammatic calculus
concepts.description: Graphical notation for manipulating morphisms in tensor categories, replacing symbolic algebraic expressions with string diagrams.

concepts.label: tensor categories
concepts.description: Categories equipped with a monoidal tensor product structure allowing compositional manipulation of morphisms.

concepts.label: strategies
concepts.description: In quantum games, player response rules defining how to map quantum questions to quantum answers.

concepts.label: correlations
concepts.description: Statistical relationships between question-answer pairs in a game, quantifying degree of coordination between players.

concepts.label: synchronicity
concepts.description: Property of a game where for every question, all players must give identical answers; stronger than classical winning condition.

concepts.label: bisynchronicity
concepts.description: Variant of synchronicity requiring symmetry in the strategy structure, relating to bidirectional consistency of answers.

concepts.label: graph homomorphism game
concepts.description: Nonlocal game where players cooperatively verify that a given function is a valid graph homomorphism between two graphs.

concepts.label: quantum graphs
concepts.description: Extension of classical graphs to the quantum setting using quantum sets as vertices and quantum functions as edges.

concepts.label: quantum graph homomorphisms
concepts.description: Maps between quantum graphs preserving quantum structure, analogous to classical graph homomorphisms in the quantum domain.

concepts.label: dagger Frobenius algebras
concepts.description: Algebraic structures with both multiplication and comultiplication operations satisfying Frobenius conditions, used in categorical quantum mechanics.

concepts.label: derivative pricing
concepts.description: Computational problem of determining the fair value of financial derivatives such as options and forwards.

concepts.label: autocallable derivatives
concepts.description: Structured financial instruments with embedded call features that automatically trigger early redemption under specified market conditions.

concepts.label: Target Accrual Redemption Forward
concepts.description: Exotic forward contract with path-dependent payoff structure accumulating coupon payments until reaching a predefined target.

concepts.label: re-parameterization method
concepts.description: Novel quantum algorithm for derivative pricing that combines pre-trained variational circuits with fault-tolerant quantum computing to reduce resource overhead.

concepts.label: variational circuits
concepts.description: Parametrized quantum circuits trained classically to prepare specific quantum states or compute expectation values.

concepts.label: T-depth
concepts.description: Circuit complexity metric measuring the depth of T-gate layers in a quantum circuit, determining fault-tolerance overhead.

concepts.label: resource requirements
concepts.description: Quantitative estimates of computational resources (qubits, gates, circuit depth, runtime) needed to execute a quantum algorithm.

concepts.label: quantum algorithm
concepts.description: Procedure exploiting quantum mechanical phenomena to solve computational problems.

concepts.label: Quantum Machine Learning
concepts.description: Machine learning algorithms and models implemented on quantum computers to exploit quantum mechanical phenomena for improved computational efficiency.

concepts.label: Generalization error bound
concepts.description: A theoretical upper limit on the difference between training error and test error, quantifying how well a model generalizes to unseen data.

concepts.label: Supervised QML
concepts.description: Quantum machine learning algorithms trained on labeled data to learn mappings between input and output variables.

concepts.label: Systematic Mapping Study
concepts.description: A structured literature review methodology that categorizes and synthesizes research findings across a broad research area.

concepts.label: Quantum hardware
concepts.description: Physical quantum computing devices and platforms used to implement quantum algorithms.

concepts.label: Optimization techniques
concepts.description: Methods and algorithms used to adjust model parameters during training to minimize loss or error functions.

concepts.label: Model robustness
concepts.description: The ability of a machine learning model to maintain performance despite perturbations, noise, or variations in input data.

concepts.label: Classical benchmark datasets
concepts.description: Standard datasets used to evaluate and compare machine learning algorithm performance across different implementations.

concepts.label: Training error
concepts.description: The prediction error of a model measured on the data used to train it.

concepts.label: Test error
concepts.description: The prediction error of a model measured on previously unseen data not used during training.

concepts.label: noise model
concepts.description: Mathematical description of error mechanisms and their statistical properties in quantum systems.

concepts.label: dephasing
concepts.description: Decoherence mechanism causing loss of quantum phase coherence and diagonal terms in the density matrix.

concepts.label: phase estimation
concepts.description: Quantum algorithm task of determining the phase of an eigenvalue of a unitary operator with high precision.

concepts.label: randomized phase estimation algorithm
concepts.description: Probabilistic quantum algorithm for phase estimation designed to be robust to noise through random sampling strategies.

concepts.label: circuit depth
concepts.description: Number of sequential quantum gate layers in a quantum circuit, determining minimum execution time and error accumulation.

concepts.label: algorithm robustness
concepts.description: Property of quantum algorithms to maintain performance guarantees and correctness despite the presence of noisy quantum hardware.

concepts.label: sample complexity
concepts.description: Number of measurement samples or algorithm repetitions required to achieve desired statistical accuracy.

concepts.label: performance guarantee
concepts.description: Formal bound or condition assuring that an algorithm achieves specified accuracy or success probability.

concepts.label: Error diagnostics
concepts.description: The process of identifying and characterizing errors in quantum systems, potentially subject to latencies or computational delays.

concepts.label: Measurement latency
concepts.description: Delay between a quantum measurement and the availability of its classical outcome, slowing feedback and error correction.

concepts.label: Decoding algorithm
concepts.description: Computational procedure that processes error syndromes to determine the appropriate error correction operation.

concepts.label: Active error correction
concepts.description: Real-time error correction strategy requiring continuous syndrome extraction and immediate correction feedback.

concepts.label: Error-correction overhead
concepts.description: Additional quantum resources (qubits, gates, time) required to implement error correction beyond the logical computation.

concepts.label: Pauli frame
concepts.description: Error correction protocol that tracks Pauli errors in software rather than applying physical correction operations.

concepts.label: Clifford frame
concepts.description: Extension of error correction allowing optimal corrections drawn from the full Clifford group rather than restricted to Pauli gates.

concepts.label: Pauli gates
concepts.description: The single-qubit X, Y, Z Pauli matrices forming the basis of the standard stabilizer formalism in quantum error correction.

concepts.label: Clifford gates
concepts.description: Quantum gates that map the Pauli group to itself; include CNOT, Hadamard, and phase gates.

concepts.label: Gate time
concepts.description: Duration required to apply a quantum gate operation in a physical quantum processor.

concepts.label: gate teleportation
concepts.description: A quantum circuit primitive that transfers quantum gates between qubits using entanglement and classical communication.

concepts.label: possibilistic simulation
concepts.description: A weak form of classical simulation where the goal is to output any string appearing with non-zero probability in the quantum circuit's output distribution.

concepts.label: single-qubit Clifford gates
concepts.description: A set of single-qubit quantum gates that generate the Clifford group, a subgroup of unitary operations preserving the stabilizer formalism.

concepts.label: constant-depth circuits
concepts.description: Classical Boolean circuits with depth bounded by a constant independent of input size, limiting computational power.

concepts.label: bounded fan-in gates
concepts.description: Logic gates with a constant upper bound on the number of input wires, typically AND, OR, NOT gates.

concepts.label: parity computation
concepts.description: The classical problem of computing the XOR of n bits, a fundamental hard problem for constant-depth circuits.

concepts.label: circuit complexity
concepts.description: The study of the resources (depth, size, fan-in) required to solve computational problems using Boolean circuits.

concepts.label: classical simulation
concepts.description: The task of reproducing the output statistics or specific outputs of a quantum circuit using a classical algorithm.

concepts.label: output distribution
concepts.description: The probability distribution over all possible measurement outcomes from a quantum circuit.

concepts.label: Surface codes
concepts.description: Topological quantum error correction codes defined on a 2D lattice with local stabilizer generators, enabling scalable fault-tolerant quantum computation.

concepts.label: Qubit systems
concepts.description: Quantum systems based on two-level quantum systems (qubits) used as the fundamental units for quantum information processing and error correction.

concepts.label: Qudit systems
concepts.description: Quantum systems based on d-level quantum systems (qudits) generalizing qubits to higher-dimensional Hilbert spaces for enhanced error correction capacity.

concepts.label: Topological quantum error correction
concepts.description: Error correction approach leveraging topological properties of quantum codes where logical information is encoded non-locally, providing robustness against local perturbations.

concepts.label: Lattice geometry
concepts.description: Spatial arrangement of qubits or qudits in a regular 2D or 3D grid structure defining the topology and interaction pattern of the quantum code.

concepts.label: Classical processing
concepts.description: Post-measurement computational steps where syndrome data is processed classically to determine error locations and optimal correction operations.

concepts.label: XZZX surface code
concepts.description: A variant of the surface code quantum error correction protocol using a modified pattern of X and Z stabilizer operators arranged in an alternating checkerboard pattern.

concepts.label: stabilizer operators
concepts.description: Commuting projectors that define the code space; measuring eigenvalues reveals error information without destroying quantum state.

concepts.label: logical qubit
concepts.description: Encoded quantum information protected by the error-correcting code against local noise and errors.

concepts.label: biased noise
concepts.description: Asymmetric error model where bit-flip and phase-flip errors occur at different rates; common in certain physical platforms.

concepts.label: matching decoder
concepts.description: Decoding algorithm based on minimum-weight perfect matching to pair and correct syndrome defects.

concepts.label: topological protection
concepts.description: Robustness of encoded information conferred by topological order; errors require non-local string operators to affect logical qubits.

concepts.label: code capacity
concepts.description: Information-theoretic limit of error correction performance when syndrome measurements are perfect and known.

concepts.label: phenomenological model
concepts.description: Error model including both qubit errors and measurement errors; more realistic than code capacity.

edges.evidence: Tianyan Quantum Cloud Platform offers cloud services demonstrating quantum advantage capabilities with...Tianyan-287.
Tianyan-287 features 105 qubits and is a superconducting quantum processor prototype.
This cloud-accessible superconducting quantum prototype...Zuchongzhi 3.0-like superconducting quantum processor.
Tianyan Quantum Cloud Platform offers cloud services demonstrating quantum advantage capabilities.

For a specific benchmark task involving random circuit sampling...the platform completes one million samples in just 18.4 minutes...state-of-the-art classical supercomputers would require approximately 16,000 years.
Single-qubit gates...at 99.90% fidelity.
Tianyan-287...achieves high operational fidelities, with single-qubit gates...at 99.90%.
Tianyan-287...readout fidelity at 98.7%.
Cqlib, an open-source SDK designed for working with quantum systems at the level of extended quantum circuits.
Cqlib designed for working with quantum systems at the level of...operators.
Cqlib designed for working with quantum systems at the level of...primitives.
To facilitate this, the platform provides access via Cqlib, an open-source SDK.
For a specific benchmark task involving random circuit sampling on a 74-qubit system...the platform completes one million samples in just 18.4 minutes.
CTQEC is investigated from the point of view of the subsystem principle, which states that protected quantum information is contained in a subsystem of the Hilbert space.
CTQEC is based on continuous weak measurements and feedback.
CTQEC is based on continuous weak measurements and feedback.
By looking at the evolution of the state in an encoded basis, the problem can be reduced to protecting a known state, allowing design of CTQEC procedures.
CTQEC procedures can be designed from protocols for the protection of a single qubit via weak measurements and weak unitary operations.

The spin-cat code is a quantum error-correcting protocol based on spin qudit encoding.
The spin-cat code exhibits superior thresholds and lower resource overheads, paving the way for achieving fault tolerance.
Error operators linear or quadratic in angular momentum components are the dominant errors corrected by spin-cat codes.
Phase errors are categorized as one of the dominant error sources and can be effectively corrected by the spin-cat code.
Amplitude errors are categorized as one of the dominant error sources addressed through measurement-free error correction.
The CNOT gate is identified as a key component of the universal gate set for spin-cat codes.
The rank-preserving CNOT gate preserves the rank of spherical tensor operators during gate operations.
Identifying a suitable universal gate set preserves dominant errors during gate operations, essential for fault tolerance.
The fault-tolerant threshold for spin-cat encoding surpasses that of standard qubit-based encodings.
A measurement-free error correction scheme is proposed to address amplitude errors without relying on syndrome measurements.
A specific implementation is based on neutral-atom quantum computing with qudits encoded in the nuclear spin of Sr.

Quantum control and Rydberg blockade are used to generate the universal gate set in the neutral-atom implementation.
The spin-cat code encodes a qubit in a large spin qudit using superpositions of angular momentum coherent states.

Kitaev's quantum double models in 2D provide some of the most commonly studied examples of topological quantum order.

The local properties of a gauge-invariant state are fully determined by specifying that its holonomies in the region are trivial.
Any two states with zero energy density in some contractible region must have the same reduced state in that region.
Local properties are determined by examining the reduced state within contractible regions.
Local properties of gauge-invariant states are not generally determined by specifying all of their non-Abelian fluxes.
The Wilson loops of lattice gauge theory do not form a complete commuting set of observables.
Wilson loops are fundamental order parameters in lattice gauge theory.
We compute the topological entanglement entropy in Kitaev's model.

A system in a superposition of spatially translated trajectories fails to thermalise despite being subject to the same thermalisation channel that would thermalise non-superposed states.
The Unruh temperature is acceleration-dependent, varying with the proper acceleration of the observer.
The Unruh effect describes thermalisation to acceleration-dependent temperature in Rindler coordinates accessible to uniformly accelerated observers.
A probe interacting with field modes undergoes thermalisation; interaction with incommensurate modes sets prevents thermalisation.
A probe accelerating in a superposition of spatial translations interacts with incommensurate sets of field modes.
In special cases where modes are orthogonal (e.g. Rindler wedges translated orthogonally to plane of motion), thermalisation does result.
The framework of QFT in relativistic noninertial reference frames explains acceleration-dependent thermalisation and Unruh effects.
Quantum-controlled application of thermalisation channels enables superpositions of thermalisation processes showing failure to equilibrate.
Recent results in relativistic quantum information independently demonstrated failure to thermalise under quantum-controlled channel application.
Recent results in quantum thermodynamics independently showed systems may fail to thermalise under quantum-controlled thermalisation.
QFT in relativistic noninertial reference frames provides explanation of thermalisation failure in superposition regimes.
Both fields independently discovered thermalisation failure phenomena, now unified through relativistic quantum effects.

Autocallable and TARF derivatives are used as benchmark use cases for quantum derivative pricing.

The re-parameterization method combines pre-trained variational circuits with fault-tolerant quantum computing.

Costly error correction is inherent to early fault-tolerant era; error correction codes enable this regime despite imperfect hardware.
Analysis of algorithm performance under two simple noise models leads to characterization of robustness.
A randomized algorithm for the task of phase estimation is introduced as the main subject.
The algorithm is designed to be robust to some degree of error, with analysis proving its robustness properties.
Dephasing is one of the simple noise models analyzed in the paper.
Analysis leads to a noise threshold below which arbitrarily high accuracy can be achieved by increasing samples.
Increasing the number of samples in the algorithm enables achieving high accuracy below noise threshold.
Maximum ratio of circuit depth to dephasing scale is computed such that performance guarantees hold; circuit depth < 0.916 × dephasing scale.
Dephasing scale is the denominator in the depth-to-noise-scale ratio determining performance bounds.
Algorithm can succeed with arbitrarily high probability as long as circuit depth condition is met, establishing performance guarantees.
Development of quantum algorithms robust to error is motivated by the need for computations during costly error correction era.
Fault tolerance depends on error diagnostics to identify and correct errors; the paper addresses latencies in this process.
Measurement latencies slow error diagnostics; the paper addresses this constraint explicitly.
Decoding algorithms are a key component of error diagnostics, translating syndromes to corrections.
Fast error diagnostics enables active error correction; slow diagnostics motivates alternatives discussed in the scheme.
Active error correction requires continuous operations, raising overhead; the paper's scheme reduces overhead by avoiding it.
Pauli frame tracking allows fault-tolerant computation without physical active correction, central to the proposed protocol.
The Clifford frame generalizes the Pauli frame by allowing corrections from the full Clifford group.
The paper states the Clifford frame protocol 'can increase error thresholds' compared to Pauli-only approaches.
The Pauli frame is defined by tracking and manipulating Pauli gates; standard error correction uses Pauli corrections.
The Clifford frame allows optimal corrections chosen from all Clifford gates, an extension beyond Pauli gates.
The paper notes reduced overhead 'when error diagnostics is much slower than the gate time'; timing relationships are critical.
The scheme achieves benefits when error diagnostics latency exceeds gate time; these timescales are central to the protocol.
Gate-teleportation circuits are among the most basic examples of computations believed to provide a quantum computational advantage.
The paper considers possibilistic simulation of gate-teleportation circuits as the computational task.
The paper focuses on single-qubit Clifford-gate-teleportation circuits.
The simulation problem cannot be solved by constant-depth classical circuits with bounded fan-in gates.
Results are obtained by a reduction to the problem of computing the parity.
Parity is a well-studied hard problem for constant-depth circuits.
Constant-depth circuits are composed of bounded fan-in gates.
Results are based on classical circuit complexity analysis of constant-depth and bounded fan-in properties.
Classical simulation aims to reproduce the output distribution or specific outputs of a quantum circuit.
Possibilistic simulation outputs any string appearing with non-zero probability in the output distribution.
Surface codes are a canonical implementation of topological quantum error correction on 2D lattices.
Surface codes are defined by local stabilizer generators forming an Abelian group.
Decoders operate on syndrome measurement outcomes to identify and correct errors.
Syndrome measurements extract error information without directly revealing the encoded logical state.
Surface codes exhibit an error threshold above which logical errors decrease exponentially with code distance.
Fast, fault-tolerant decoders are essential for achieving error correction below the threshold.
Qubit surface codes encode logical qubits in 2D lattices of physical qubits.
Qudit surface codes extend qubit codes to higher-dimensional systems for enhanced error correction capacity.
Surface codes are defined on 2D square lattices with local stabilizer operators at plaquettes and vertices.
Decoding algorithms rely on classical post-processing of syndrome measurements to determine recovery operations.
Scalable fault-tolerant quantum computation depends on achieving exponential suppression of logical errors with code size.
Operating below error threshold is necessary for logical error suppression and therefore scalability.
XZZX is a variant of the surface code with modified stabilizer operator arrangement.
The XZZX code uses an alternating checkerboard pattern of X and Z stabilizers on the lattice.
The surface code encodes and protects logical qubits against local errors through topological order.
Measuring stabilizer eigenvalues reveals error syndromes without destroying the encoded state.
Decoded syndrome outcomes feed into classical decoding algorithms to infer and correct errors.
XZZX surface code shows improved error thresholds and performance under biased noise models compared to standard surface codes.
Classical decoding corrects syndrome-identified errors, preventing them from corrupting the encoded logical qubit.
Higher code distance improves logical error scaling below threshold; larger lattices suppress errors exponentially.
Below error threshold, topological protection becomes effective and logical error rates improve exponentially with distance.
Minimum-weight matching is a specific practical decoding algorithm for surface codes.
Code capacity provides an upper bound on achievable error thresholds when syndrome measurements are ideal.
Realistic phenomenological error models including measurement errors typically yield lower thresholds than code capacity.
XZZX exhibits higher error thresholds under biased noise compared to standard surface codes, particularly for depolarizing and dephasing-dominated models.
Fidelity quantifies how well the encoded logical qubit state is preserved against errors during computation.
